|





Vi. REQUIREMENTS AND CRITERIA FOR AN
EAST-WEST EXPRESSWAY

Any route for an East-West Expressway should satisfy the following

requirements:

1. It should be planned in such a way that it will be approvable for
inclusion in the National Interstate Highway System and thus be
eligible for 90% Federal grant. Specifically this means that:
(a) At its eastern termination it must connect with the proposed

North-East Expressway leading to Philadelphia.

(b) At its western termination it must cross the city line at about
Cooks Lane so as to connect with the proposed freeway
going toward Frederick.

(c) It must be possible to meet Federal design standards.
2. A feasible interchange with the Jones Falls Expressway must be
possible.
3. It should provide good service to the central business district.
If more than one route can be developed meeting the above require-
ments, then judgment as to the relative desirability of the different routes
should be based upon the following factors:
1. Benefits to traffic.
(a) Extent to which route conforms to traffic desire lines.
(b) Extent of relief to presently congested streets.

(c) Extent to which incidental benefits (street widenings, etc.)
are made possible.

35

2. Stimulus to new building or to redevelopment in adjacent areas.
3. Benefit to the central business district including the retail trade
center, Charles Center, and the Civic Center.
4. Benefits to the economic life of the City—commerce, industry,
port, etc.
5. Blighting effect as measured by:
(a) Extent to which route splits established residential neighbor-
hoods.
(b) Extent to which route separates areas which for economic
reasons should be in close proximity.
(¢) Proximity to high grade residential areas.
(d) Proximity of elevated structures to any residential areas.
(e) Close proximity of elevated structures to retail or office use.
Quantity and quality of dwellings to be demolished.

Effect on assessed valuations.

Total cost.

Significant or important properties to be taken:

(a) Churches

(b) Moderately large or large structures not in poor condition.

(c) Takings which would utilize significant amounts of vacant
land otherwise desirable and available for industrial ex-
pansion.

The above factors are not necessarily listed in order of importance.

o o n

e e e e T s e e e e LT
